sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Observe, then, Protarchus, what the doctrine is which you are now to accept from Philebus, and what our doctrine is, against which you are to argue, if you do not agree with it. Shall we make a brief statement of each of them?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Very well: Philebus says that to all living beings enjoyment and pleasure and gaiety and whatever accords with that sort of thing are a good; whereas our contention is that not these, but wisdom and thought and memory and their kindred, right opinion and true reasonings, are better and more excellent than pleasure for all who are capable of taking part in them, and that for all those now existing or to come who can partake of them they are the most advantageous of all things. Those are pretty nearly the two doctrines we maintain, are they not, Philebus?

sp.speaker: Philebus
sp.p: Yes, Socrates, exactly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do you, Protarchus, accept this doctrine which is now committed to you?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I must accept it; for our handsome Philebus has withdrawn.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And must the truth about these doctrines be attained by every possible means?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, it must.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then let us further agree to this:

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: To what?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That each of us will next try to prove clearly that it is a condition and disposition of the soul which can make life happy for all human beings. Is not that what we are going to do?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then you will show that it is the condition of pleasure, and I that it is that of wisdom?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What if some other life be found superior to these two? Then if that life is found to be more akin to pleasure, both of us are defeated, are we not, by the life which has firm possession of this superiority, but the life of pleasure is victor over the life of wisdom.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if it is more akin to wisdom, then wisdom is victorious and pleasure is vanquished? Do you agree to that? Or what do you say?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, I at least am satisfied with that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But how about you, Philebus? What do you say?

sp.speaker: Philebus
sp.p: I think and always shall think that pleasure is the victor. But you, Protarchus, will make your own decision.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Since you entrusted the argument to me, Philebus, you can no longer dictate whether to make the agreement with Socrates or not.

sp.speaker: Philebus
sp.p: True; and for that reason I wash my hands of it and now call upon the goddessThe goddess of Pleasure,*(hdonh/personified. herself to witness that I do so.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: And we also will bear witness to these words of yours. But all the same, Socrates, Philebus may agree or do as he likes, let us try to finish our argument in due order.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We must try, and let us begin with the very goddess who Philebus says is spoken of as Aphrodite but is most truly named Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: My awe, Protarchus, in respect to the names of the gods is always beyond the greatest human fear. And now I call Aphrodite by that name which is agreeable to her; but pleasure I know has various aspects, and since, as I said, we are to begin with her, we must consider and examine what her nature is. For, when you just simply hear her name, she is only one thing, but surely she takes on all sorts of shapes which are even, in a way, unlike each other. For instance, we say that the man who lives without restraint has pleasure, and that the self-restrained man takes pleasure in his very self-restraint; and again that the fool who is full of foolish opinions and hopes is pleased, and also that the wise man takes pleasure in his very wisdom. And would not any person who said these two kinds of pleasure were like each other be rightly regarded as a fool?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No, Socrates, for though they spring from opposite sources, they are not in themselves opposed to one another; for how can pleasure help being of all things most like pleasure, that is, like itself?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, my friend, and color is like color in so far as every one of them is a color they will all be the same, yet we all recognize that black is not only different from white, but is its exact opposite. And so, too, figure is like figure; they are all one in kind but the parts of the kind are in some instances absolutely opposed to each other, and in other cases there is endless variety of difference; and we can find many other examples of such relations. Do not, therefore, rely upon this argument, which makes all the most absolute opposites identical. I am afraid we shall find some pleasures the opposites of other pleasures.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Perhaps; but why will that injure my contention?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because I shall say that, although they are unlike, you apply to them a different designation. For you say that all pleasant things are good. Now no argument contends that pleasant things are not pleasant; but whereas most of them are bad and only some are good, as we assert, nevertheless you call them all good, though you confess, if forced to it by argument, that they are unlike. Now what is the identical element which exists in the good and bad pleasures alike and makes you call them all a good?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What do you mean, Socrates? Do you suppose anyone who asserts that the good is pleasure will concede, or will endure to hear you say, that some pleasures are good and others bad?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But you will concede that they are unlike and in some instances opposed to each other.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Not in so far as they are pleasures.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Here we are again at the same old argument, Protarchus, and we shall presently assert that one pleasure is not different from another, but all pleasures are alike, and the examples just cited do not affect us at all, but we shall behave and talk just like the most worthless and inexperienced reasoners.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: In what way do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Why, if I have the face to imitate you and to defend myself by saying that the utterly unlike is most completely like that which is most utterly unlike it, I can say the same things you said, and we shall prove ourselves to be excessively inexperienced, and our argument will be shipwrecked and lost. Let us, then, back her out, and perhaps if we start fair again we may come to an agreement.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How? Tell me.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Assume, Protarchus, that I am questioned in turn by you.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What question do I ask?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Whether wisdom and knowledge and intellect and all the things which I said at first were good, when you asked me what is good, will not have the same fate as this argument of yours.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It will appear that the forms of knowledge collectively are many and some of them are unlike each other; but if some of them turn out to be actually opposites, should I be fit to engage in dialectics now if, through fear of just that, I should say that no form of knowledge is unlike any other, and then, as a consequence, our argument should vanish and be lost, like a tale that is told, and we ourselves should be saved by clinging to some irrational notion?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No, that must never be, except the part about our being saved. However, I like the equal treatment of your doctrine and mine. Let us grant that pleasures are many and unlike and that the forms of knowledge are many and different.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: With no concealment, then, Protarchus, of the difference between my good and yours, but with fair and open acknowledgement of it, let us be bold and see if perchance on examination they will tell us whether we should say that pleasure is the good, or wisdom, or some other third principle. For surely the object of our present controversy is not to gain the victory for my assertions or yours, but both of us must fight for the most perfect truth.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, we must.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then let us establish this principle still more firmly by means of an agreement.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What principle?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The principle which gives trouble to all men, to some of them sometimes against their will.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Speak more plainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I mean the principle which came in our way just now; its nature is quite marvellous. For the assertions that one is many and many are one are marvellous, and it is easy to dispute with anyone who makes either of them.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You mean when a person says that I, Protarchus, am by nature one and that there are also many of me which are opposites of each other, asserting that I, the same Protarchus, am great and small and heavy and light and countless other things?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Those wonders concerning the one and the many which you have mentioned, Protarchus, are common property, and almost everybody is agreed that they ought to be disregarded because they are childish and easy and great hindrances to speculation; and this sort of thing also should be disregarded, when a man in his discussion divides the members and likewise the parts of anything, acknowledges that they all collectively are that one thing, and then mockingly refutes himself because he has been compelled to declare miracles—that the one is many and infinite and the many only one.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: But what other wonders do you mean, Socrates, in relation to this same principle, which are not yet common property and generally acknowledged?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I mean, my boy, when a person postulates unity which is not the unity of one of the things which come into being and perish, as in the examples we had just now. For in cases of a unity of that sort, as I just said, it is agreed that refutation is needless. But when the assertion is made that man is one, or ox is one, or beauty is one, or the good is one, the intense interest in these and similar unities becomes disagreement and controversy.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The first question is whether we should believe that such unities really exist; the second, how these unities, each of which is one, always the same, and admitting neither generation nor destruction, can nevertheless be permanently this one unity; and the third, how in the infinite number of things which come into being this unity, whether we are to assume that it is dispersed and has become many, or that it is entirely separated from itself—which would seem to be the most impossible notion of all being the same and one, is to be at the same time in one and in many. These are the questions, Protarchus, about this kind of one and many, not those others, which cause the utmost perplexity, if ill solved, and are, if well solved, of the greatest assistance.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Then is it now, Socrates, our first duty to thresh this matter out?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, that is what I should say.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You may assume, then, that we are all willing to agree with you about that; and perhaps it is best not to ask Philebus any questions; let sleeping dogs lie.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Very well; then where shall we begin this great and vastly complicated battle about the matters at issue? Shall we start at this point?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: At what point?

sp.speaker: Socrates
Protarchus
sp.p: Socrates, do you not see how many we are and that we are all young men? Are you not afraid that we shall join with Philebus and attack you, if you revile us? However—for we understand your meaning—if there is any way or means of removing this confusion gently from our discussion and finding some better road than this to bring us towards the goal of our argument, kindly lead on, and we will do our best to follow for our present discussion, Socrates, is no trifling matter.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No, it is not, boys, as Philebus calls you; and there certainly is no better road, nor can there ever be, than that which I have always loved, though it has often deserted me, leaving me lonely and forlorn.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is the road? Only tell us.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: One which is easy to point out, but very difficult to follow for through it all the inventions of art have been brought to light. See this is the road I mean.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Go on what is it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: A gift of gods to men, as I believe, was tossed down from some divine source through the agency of a Prometheus together with a gleaming fire; and the ancients, who were better than we and lived nearer the gods, handed down the tradition that all the things which are ever said to exist are sprung from one and many and have inherent in them the finite and the infinite. This being the way in which these things are arranged, we must always assume that there is in every case one idea of everything and must look for it—for we shall find that it is there—and if we get a grasp of this, we must look next for two, if there be two, and if not, for three or some other number; and again we must treat each of those units in the same way, until we can see not only that the original unit is one and many and infinite, but just how many it is. And we must not apply the idea of infinite to plurality until we have a view of its whole number between infinity and one; then, and not before, we may let each unit of everything pass on unhindered into infinity. The gods, then, as I said, handed down to us this mode of investigating, learning, and teaching one another; but the wise men of the present day make the one and the many too quickly or too slowly, in haphazard fashion, and they put infinity immediately after unity; they disregard all that lies between them, and this it is which distinguishes between the dialectic and the disputatious methods of discussion.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I think I understand you in part, Socrates, but I need a clearer statement of some things.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Surely my meaning, Protarchus, is made clear in the letters of the alphabet, which you were taught as a child; so learn it from them.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Sound, which passes out through the mouth of each and all of us, is one, and yet again it is infinite in number.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And one of us is no wiser than the other merely for knowing that it is infinite or that it is one; but that which makes each of us a grammarian is the knowledge of the number and nature of sounds.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And it is this same knowledge which makes the musician.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Sound is one in the art of music also, so far as that art is concerned.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we may say that there are two sounds, low and high, and a third, which is the intermediate, may we not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But knowledge of these facts would not suffice to make you a musician, although ignorance of them would make you, if I may say so, quite worthless in respect to music.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But, my friend, when you have grasped the number and quality of the intervals of the voice in respect to high and low pitch, and the limits of the intervals, and all the combinations derived from them, which the men of former times discovered and handed down to us, their successors, with the traditional name of harmonies, and also the corresponding effects in the movements of the body, which they say are measured by numbers and must be called rhythms and measures—and they say that we must also understand that every one and many should be considered in this way— when you have thus grasped the facts, you have become a musician, and when by considering it in this way you have obtained a grasp of any other unity of all those which exist, you have become wise in respect to that unity. But the infinite number of individuals and the infinite number in each of them makes you in every instance indefinite in thought and of no account and not to be considered among the wise, so long as you have never fixed your eye upon any definite number in anything.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I think, Philebus, that what Socrates has said is excellent.

sp.speaker: Philebus
sp.p: So do I; it is excellent in itself, but why has he said it now to us, and what purpose is there in it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Protarchus, that is a very proper question which Philebus has asked us.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly it is, so please answer it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I will, when I have said a little more on just this subject. For if a person begins with some unity or other, he must, as I was saying, not turn immediately to infinity, but to some definite number; now just so, conversely, when he has to take the infinite first, he must not turn immediately to the one, but must think of some number which possesses in each case some plurality, and must end by passing from all to one. Let us revert to the letters of the alphabet to illustrate this.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: When some one, whether god or godlike man,—there is an Egyptian story that his name was Theuth—observed that sound was infinite, he was the first to notice that the vowel sounds in that infinity were not one, but many, and again that there were other elements which were not vowels but did have a sonant quality, and that these also had a definite number; and he distinguished a third kind of letters which we now call mutes. Then he divided the mutes until he distinguished each individual one, and he treated the vowels and semivowels in the same way, until he knew the number of them and gave to each and all the name of letters. Perceiving, however, that none of us could learn any one of them alone by itself without learning them all, and considering that this was a common bond which made them in a way all one, he assigned to them all a single science and called it grammar.

sp.speaker: Philebus
sp.p: I understand that more clearly than the earlier statement, Protarchus, so far as the reciprocal relations of the one and the many are concerned, but I still feel the same lack as a little while ago.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you mean, Philebus, that you do not see what this has to do with the question?

sp.speaker: Philebus
sp.p: Yes; that is what Protarchus and I have been trying to discover for a long time.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Really, have you been trying, as you say, for long time to discover it, when it was close to you all the while?

sp.speaker: Philebus
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Was not our discussion from the beginning about wisdom and pleasure and which of them is preferable?

sp.speaker: Philebus
sp.p: Yes, of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And surely we say that each of them is one.

sp.speaker: Philebus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: This, then, is precisely the question which the previous discussion puts to us: How is each of them one and many, and how is it that they are not immediately infinite, but each possesses a definite number, before the individual phenomena become infinite?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Philebus, somehow or other Socrates has led us round and plunged us into a serious question. Consider which of us shall answer it. Perhaps it is ridiculous that I, after taking your place in entire charge of the argument, should ask you to come back and answer this question because I cannot do so, but I think it would be still more ridiculous if neither of us could answer. Consider, then, what we are to do. For I think Socrates is asking us whether there are or are not kinds of pleasure, how many kinds there are, and what their nature is, and the same of wisdom.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You are quite right, son of Callias; for, as our previous discussion showed, unless we can do this in the case of every unity, every like, every same, and their opposites, none of us can ever be of any use in anything.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That, Socrates, seems pretty likely to be true. However, it is splendid for the wise man to know everything, but the next best thing, it seems, is not to be ignorant of himself. I will tell you why I say that at this moment. You, Socrates, have granted to all of us this conversation and your cooperation for the purpose of determining what is the best of human possessions. For when Philebus said it was pleasure and gaiety and enjoyment and all that sort of thing, you objected and said it was not those things, but another sort, and we very properly keep reminding ourselves voluntarily of this, in order that both claims may be present in our memory for examination. You, as it appears, assert that the good which is rightly to be called better than pleasure is mind, knowledge, intelligence, art, and all their kin; you say we ought to acquire these, not that other sort. When those two claims were made and an argument arose, we playfully threatened that we would not let you go home until the discussion was brought to some satisfactory conclusion. You agreed and put yourself at our disposal for that purpose. Now, we say that, as children put it, you cannot take back a gift once fairly given. So cease this way of meeting all that we say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What way do you mean?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I mean puzzling us and asking questions to which we cannot at the moment give a satisfactory answer. Let us not imagine that the end of our present discussion is a mere puzzling of us all, but if we cannot answer, you must do so; for you gave us a promise. Consider, therefore, whether you yourself must distinguish the kinds of pleasure and knowledge or will let that go, in case you are able and willing to make clear in some other way the matters now at issue among us.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I need no longer anticipate anything terrible, since you put it in that way; for the words “in case you are willing” relieve me of all fear. And besides, I think some god has given me a vague recollection.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How is that, and what is the recollection about?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I remember now having heard long ago in a dream, or perhaps when I was awake, some talk about pleasure and wisdom to the effect that neither of the two is the good, but some third thing, different from them and better than both. However, if this be now clearly proved to us, pleasure is deprived of victory for the good would no longer be identical with it. Is not that true?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we shall have, in my opinion, no longer any need of distinguishing the kinds of pleasure. But the progress of the discussion will make that still clearer.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Excellent! Just go on as you have begun.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: First, then, let us agree on some further small points.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is the nature of the good necessarily perfect or imperfect?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: The most perfect of all things, surely, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, and is the good sufficient?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course; so that it surpasses all other things in sufficiency.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And nothing, I should say, is more certain about it than that every intelligent being pursues it, desires it, wishes to catch and get possession of it, and has no interest in anything in which the good is not included.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: There is no denying that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us, then, look at the life of pleasure and the life of wisdom separately and consider and judge them.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let there be no wisdom in the life of pleasure and no pleasure in the life of wisdom. For if either of them is the good, it cannot have need of anything else, and if, either be found to need anything, we can no longer regard it as our true good.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No, of course not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we then undertake to test them through you?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then answer.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Ask.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Would you, Protarchus, be willing to live your whole life in the enjoyment of the greatest pleasures?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course I should.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Would you think you needed anything further, if you were in complete possession of that enjoyment?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But consider whether you would not have some need of wisdom and intelligence and power of calculating your wants and the like.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Why should I? If I have enjoyment, I have everything.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then living thus you would enjoy the greatest pleasures all your life?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes; why not?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if you did not possess mind or memory or knowledge or true opinion, in the first place, you would not know whether you were enjoying your pleasures or not. That must be true, since you are utterly devoid of intellect, must it not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, it must.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And likewise, if you had no memory you could not even remember that you ever did enjoy pleasure, and no recollection whatever of present pleasure could remain with you; if you had no true opinion you could not think you were enjoying pleasure at the time when you were enjoying it, and if you were without power of calculation you would not be able to calculate that you would enjoy it in the future; your life would not be that of a man, but of a mollusc or some other shell-fish like the oyster. Is that true, or can we imagine any other result?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: We certainly cannot.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And can we choose such a life?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: This argument, Socrates, has made me utterly speechless for the present.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, let us not give in yet. Let us take up the life of mind and scrutinize that in turn.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What sort of life do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I ask whether anyone would be willing to live possessing wisdom and mind and knowledge and perfect memory of all things, but having no share, great or small, in pleasure, or in pain, for that matter, but being utterly unaffected by everything of that sort.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Neither of the two lives can ever appear desirable to me, Socrates, or, I think, to anyone else.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How about the combined life, Protarchus, made up by a union of the two?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You mean a union of pleasure with mind or wisdom?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, I mean a union of such elements.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Every one will prefer this life to either of the two others—yes, every single person without exception.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then do we understand the consequences of what we are now saying?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly. Three lives have been proposed, and of two of them neither is sufficient or desirable for man or any other living being.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then is it not already clear that neither of these two contained the good for if it did contain the good, it would be sufficient and perfect, and such as to be chosen by all living creatures which would be able to live thus all their lives; and if any of us chose anything else, he would be choosing contrary to the nature of the truly desirable, not of his own free will, but from ignorance or some unfortunate necessity.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That seems at any rate to be true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And so I think we have sufficiently proved that PhilebusÕs divinity is not to be considered identical with the good.

sp.speaker: Philebus
sp.p: But neither is your “mind” the good, Socrates; it will be open to the same objections.

sp.speaker: Socrates
Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly, Socrates, it seems to me that pleasure has fought for the victory and has fallen in this bout, knocked down by your words. And we can only say, as it seems, that mind was wise in not laying claim to the victory; for it would have met with the same fate. Now pleasure, if she were to lose the second prize, would be deeply humiliated in the eyes of her lovers; for she would no longer appear even to them so lovely as before.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, then, is it not better to leave her now and not to pain her by testing her to the utmost and proving her in the wrong?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Nonsense, Socrates!

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nonsense because I spoke of paining pleasure, and that is impossible?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Not only that, but because you do not understand that not one of us will let you go yet until you have finished the argument about these matters.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Whew, Protarchus! Then we have a long discussion before us, and not an easy one, either, this time. For in going ahead to fight mindÕs battle for the second place, I think I need a new contrivance—other weapons, as it were, than those of our previous discussion, though perhaps some of the old ones will serve. Must I then go on?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course you must.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then let us try to be careful in making our beginning.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What kind of a beginning do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us divide all things that now exist in the universe into two, or rather, if you please, three classes.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Please tell us on what principle you would divide them.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us take some of the subjects of our present discussion.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What subjects?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We said that God revealed in the universe two elements, the infinite and the finite, did we not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us, then, assume these as two of our classes, and a third, made by combining these two. But I cut a ridiculous figure, it seems, when I attempt a division into classes and an enumeration.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What do you mean, my friend?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I think we need a fourth class besides.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Tell us what it is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Note the cause of the combination of those two and assume that as the fourth in addition to the previous three.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: And then will you not need a fifth, which has the power of separation?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Perhaps; but not at present, I think. However, if we do need a fifth, you will pardon me for going after it.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: First, then, let us take three of the four and, as we see that two of these are split up and scattered each one into many, let us try, by collecting each of them again into one, to learn how each of them was both one and many.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: If you could tell me more clearly about them, I might be able to follow you.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I mean, then, that the two which I select are the same which I mentioned before, the infinite and the finite. I will try to show that the infinite is, in a certain sense, many; the finite can wait.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Consider then. What I ask you to consider is difficult and debatable; but consider it all the same. In the first place, take hotter and colder and see whether you can conceive any limit of them, or whether the more and less which dwell in their very nature do not, so long as they continue to dwell therein, preclude the possibility of any end; for if there were any end of them, the more and less would themselves be ended.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But always, we affirm, in the hotter and colder there is the more and less.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Always, then, the argument shows that these two have no end; and being endless, they are of course infinite.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Most emphatically, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I am glad you responded, my dear Protarchus, and reminded me that the word “emphatically “which you have just used, and the word “gently” have the same force as “more” and “less.” For wherever they are present, they do not allow any definite quantity to exist; they always introduce in every instance a comparison—more emphatic than that which is quieter, or vice versa—and thus they create the relation of more and less, thereby doing away with fixed quantity. For, as I said just now, if they did not abolish quantity, but allowed it and measure to make their appearance in the abode of the more and less, the emphatically and gently, those latter would be banished from their own proper place. When once they had accepted definite quantity, they would no longer be hotter or colder; for hotter and colder are always progressing and never stationary; but quantity is at rest and does not progress. By this reasoning hotter and its opposite are shown to be infinite.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That appears to be the case, Socrates; but, as you said, these subjects are not easy to follow. Perhaps, however, continued repetition might lead to a satisfactory agreement between the questioner and him who is questioned.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That is a good suggestion, and I must try to carry it out. However, to avoid waste of time in discussing all the individual examples, see if we can accept this as a designation of the infinite.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Accept what?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: All things which appear to us to become more or less, or to admit of emphatic and gentle and excessive and the like, are to be put in the class of the infinite as their unity, in accordance with what we said a while ago, if you remember, that we ought to collect all things that are scattered and split up and impress upon them to the best of our ability the seal of some single nature.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I remember.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the things which do not admit of more and less and the like, but do admit of all that is opposed to them—first equality and the equal, then the double, and anything which is a definite number or measure in relation to such a number or measure— all these might properly be assigned to the class of the finite. What do you say to that?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Excellent, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, what shall we say is the nature of the third class, made by combining these two?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You will tell me, I fancy, by answering your own question.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nay, a god will do so, if any god will give ear to my prayers.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Pray, then, and watch.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I am watching; and I think, Protarchus, one of the gods has this moment been gracious unto me.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What do you mean, and what evidence have you?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I will tell you, of course. Just follow what I say.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Say on.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We spoke just now of hotter and colder, did we not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Add to them drier and wetter, more and less, quicker and slower, greater and smaller, and all that we assigned before to the class which unites more and less.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You mean the class of the infinite?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes. Mix with that the second class, the offspring of the limit.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What class do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The class of the finite, which we ought just now to have reduced to unity, as we did that of the infinite. We have not done that, but perhaps we shall even now accomplish the same end, if these two are both unified and then the third class is revealed.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What third class, and what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The class of the equal and double and everything which puts an end to the differences between opposites and makes them commensurable and harmonious by the introduction of number.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I understand. I think you mean that by mixture of these elements certain results are produced in each instance.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, you are right.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In cases of illness, does not the proper combination of these elements produce health?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And in the acute and the grave, the quick and the slow, which are unlimited, the addition of these same elements creates a limit and establishes the whole art of music in all its perfection, does it not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And again in the case of cold and hot weather, the introduction of these elements removes the excess and indefiniteness and creates moderation and harmony.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Assuredly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And thence arise the seasons and all the beauties of our world, by mixture of the infinite with the finite?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: There are countless other things which I pass over, such as health, beauty, and strength of the body and the many glorious beauties of the soul. For this goddess,This goddess may be*MOUSIKH/(in which caseE)GGENOME/NHthe reading of T and G, would be preferable toE)GGENO/MENAabove), not music in the restricted modern sense, but the spirit of numbers and measure which underlies all music, and all the beauties of the world; or the goddess may be mentioned here in reference (and opposition) to the goddess Pleasure (12 B); she is the nameless deity who makes Pleasure and all others conform to her rules. my fair Philebus, beholding the violence and universal wickedness which prevailed, since there was no limit of pleasures or of indulgence in them, established law and order, which contain a limit. You say she did harm; I say, on the contrary, she brought salvation. What do you think, Protarchus?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What you say, Socrates, pleases me greatly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I have spoken of these three classes, you observe.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, I believe I understand; I think you mean that the infinite is one class and the finite is another class among existing things; but what you wish to designate as the third class, I do not comprehend very well.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No, because the multitude which springs up in the third class overpowers you and yet the infinite also comprised many classes, nevertheless, since they were sealed with the seal of the more and less, they were seen to be of one class.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the finite, again, did not contain many classes, nor were we disturbed about its natural unity.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No, not at all. And as to the third class, understand that I mean every offspring of these two which comes into being as a result of the measures created by the cooperation of the finite.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I understand.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But we said there was, in addition to three classes, a fourth to be investigated. Let us do that together. See whether you think that everything which comes into being must necessarily come into being through a cause.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, I do; for how could it come into being apart from a cause?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Does not the nature of that which makes or creates differ only in name from the cause, and may not the creative agent and the cause be properly considered one?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And, again, we shall find that, on the same principle, that which is made or created differs in name only from that which comes into being, shall we not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: We shall.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the creative agent always naturally leads, and that which is created follows after it as it comes into being?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the cause and that which is the servant of the cause for the purpose of generation are not the same.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Did not the things which come into being and the things out of which they come into being furnish us all the three classes?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that which produces all these, the cause, we call the fourth, as it has been satisfactorily shown to be distinct from the others?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, it is distinct.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It is, then, proper, now that we have distinguished the four, to make sure that we remember them separately by enumerating them in order.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The first, then, I call infinite, the second limit or finite, and the third something generated by a mixture of these two. And should I be making any mistake if I called the cause of this mixture and creation the fourth?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now what is the next step in our argument, and what was our purpose in coming to the point we have reached? Was it not this? We were trying to find out whether the second place belonged to pleasure or to wisdom, were we not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, we were.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And may we not, perhaps, now that we have finished with these points, be better able to come to a decision about the first and second places, which was the original subject of our discussion?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then; we decided that the mixed life of pleasure and wisdom was the victor, did we not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do we not see what kind of life this is, and to what class it belongs?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course we do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We shall say that it belongs to the third class; for that class is not formed by mixture of any two things, but of all the things which belong to the infinite, bound by the finite; and therefore this victorious life would rightly be considered a part of this class.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite rightly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, what of your life, Philebus, of unmixed pleasure? In which of the aforesaid classes may it properly be said to belong? But before you tell me, please answer this question.

sp.speaker: Philebus
sp.p: Ask your question.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Have pleasure and pain a limit, or are they among the things which admit of more and less?

sp.speaker: Philebus
sp.p: Yes, they are among those which admit of the more, Socrates; for pleasure would not be absolute good if it were not infinite in number and degree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor would pain, Philebus, be absolute evil; so it is not the infinite which supplies any element of good in pleasure; we must look for something else. Well, I grant you that pleasure and pain are in the class of the infinite but to which of the aforesaid classes, Protarchus and Philebus, can we now without irreverence assign wisdom, knowledge, and mind? I think we must find the right answer to this question, for our danger is great if we fail.

sp.speaker: Philebus
sp.p: Oh Socrates, you exalt your own god.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you your goddess, my friend. But the question calls for an answer, all the same.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Socrates is right, Philebus; you ought to do as he asks.

sp.speaker: Philebus
sp.p: Did you not, Protarchus, elect to reply in my place?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes; but now I am somewhat at a loss, and I ask you, Socrates, to be our spokesman yourself, that we may not select the wrong representative and so say something improper.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I must do as you ask, Protarchus; and it is not difficult. But did I really, as Philebus said, embarrass you by playfully exalting my god, when I asked to what class mind and knowledge should be assigned?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You certainly did, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yet the answer is easy; for all philosophers agree—whereby they really exalt themselves—that mind is king of heaven and earth. Perhaps they are right. But let us, if you please, investigate the question of its class more at length.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Speak just as you like, Socrates. Do not consider length, so far as we are concerned you cannot bore us.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Good. Then let us begin by asking a question.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is the question?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we say, Protarchus, that all things and this which is called the universe are governed by an irrational and fortuitous power and mere chance, or, on the contrary, as our forefathers said, are ordered and directed by mind and a marvellous wisdom?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: The two points of view have nothing in common, my wonderful Socrates. For what you are now saying seems to me actually impious. But the assertion that mind orders all things is worthy of the aspect of the world, of sun, moon, stars, and the whole revolving universe; I can never say or think anything else about it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you, then, think we should assent to this and agree in the doctrine of our predecessors, not merely intending to repeat the words of others, with no risk to ourselves, but ready to share with them in the risk and the blame, if any clever man declares that this world is not thus ordered, but is without order?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, of course I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then observe the argument that now comes against us.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We see the elements which belong to the natures of all living beings, fire, water, air, and earth—or, as the storm-tossed mariners say, land in sight— in the constitution of the universe.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly and we are truly storm-tossed in the puzzling cross-currents of this discussion.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, here is a point for you to consider in relation to each of these elements as it exists in us.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is the point?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Each element in us is small and poor and in no way pure at all or endowed with the power which is worthy of its nature. Take one example and apply it to all. Fire, for instance, exists in us and also in the universe.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that which is in us is small, weak, and poor, but that which is in the universe is marvellous in quantity, beauty, and every power which belongs to fire.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What you say is very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, is the fire of the universe nourished, originated, and ruled by the fire within us, or, on the contrary, does my fire, and yours, and that of all living beings derive nourishment and all that from the universal fire?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That question does not even deserve an answer.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: True; and you will, I fancy, say the same of the earth which is in us living creatures and that which is in the universe, and concerning all the other elements about which I asked a moment ago your answer will be the same.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes. Who could answer otherwise without being called a lunatic?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nobody, I fancy. Now follow the next step. When we see that all the aforesaid elements are gathered together into a unit, do we not call them a body?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Apply the same line of thought to that which we call the universe. It would likewise be a body, being composed of the same elements.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Does our body derive, obtain, and possess from that body, or that body from ours, nourishment and everything else that we mentioned just now?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That, Socrates, is another question not worth asking.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, is this next one worth asking? What will you say to it?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we not say that our body has a soul?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Clearly we shall.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Where did it get it, Protarchus, unless the body of the universe had a soul, since that body has the same elements as ours, only in every way superior?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Clearly it could get it from no other source.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No; for we surely do not believe, Protarchus, that of those four elements, the finite, the infinite, the combination, and the element of cause which exists in all things, this last, which gives to our bodies souls and the art of physical exercise and medical treatment when the body is ill, and which is in general a composing and healing power, is called the sum of all wisdom, and yet, while these same elements exist in the entire heaven and in great parts thereof, and area moreover, fair and pure, there is no means of including among them that nature which is the fairest and most precious of all.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly there would be no sense in that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if that is not the case, it would be better to follow the other line of thought and say, as we have often said, that there is in the universe a plentiful infinite and a sufficient limit, and in addition a by no means feeble cause which orders and arranges years and seasons and months, and may most justly be called wisdom and mind.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, most justly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Surely reason and mind could never come into being without soul.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No, never.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then in the nature of Zeus you would say that a kingly soul and a kingly mind were implanted through the power of the cause, and in other deities other noble qualities from which they derive their favorite epithets.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now do not imagine, Protarchus, that this is mere idle talk of mine; it confirms the utterances of those who declared of oldAnaxagoras and probably some now unknown precursors. that mind always rules the universe.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And to my question it has furnished the reply that mind belongs to that one of our four classes which was called the cause of all. Now, you see, you have at last my answer.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, and a very sufficient one and yet you answered without my knowing it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, Protarchus, for sometimes a joke is a restful change from serious talk.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We have now, then, my friend, pretty clearly shown to what class mind belongs and what power it possesses.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And likewise the class of pleasure was made clear some time ago.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us, then, remember concerning both of them that mind was akin to cause and belonged more or less to that class, and that pleasure was itself infinite and belonged to the class which, in and by itself, has not and never will have either beginning or middle or end.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: We will remember that, of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Our next task is to see in what and by means of what feeling each of them comes into being whenever they do come into being. We will take pleasure first and discuss these questions in relation to pleasure, as we examined its class first. But we cannot examine pleasure successfully apart from pain.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: If that is our proper path, let us follow it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you agree with us about the origin of pleasure?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What do you think it is?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I think pain and pleasure naturally originate in the combined class.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Please, my dear Socrates, remind us which of the aforesaid classes you mean by the combined class.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I will do so, as well as I can, my brilliant friend.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: By combined class, then, let us understand that which we said was the third of the four.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: The one you mentioned after the infinite and the finite, and in which you put health and also, I believe, harmony?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You are quite right. Now please pay very close attention.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I will. Say on.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I say, then, that when, in us living beings, harmony is broken up, a disruption of nature and a generation of pain also take place at the same moment.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What you say is very likely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if harmony is recomposed and returns to its own nature, then I say that pleasure is generated, if I may speak in the fewest and briefest words about matters of the highest import.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I think you are right, Socrates; but let us try to be more explicit.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It is easiest to understand common and obvious examples, is it not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What examples?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is hunger a kind of breaking up and a pain?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And eating, which is a filling up again, is a pleasure?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Thirst again is a destruction and a pain, but the filling with moisture of that which was dried up is a pleasure. Then, too, the unnatural dissolution and disintegration we experience through heat are a pain, but the natural restoration and cooling are a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the unnatural hardening of the moisture in an animal through cold is pain; but the natural course of the elements returning to their place and separating is a pleasure. See, in short, if you think it is a reasonable statement that whenever in the class of living beings, which, as I said before, arises out of the natural union of the infinite and the finite, that union is destroyed, the destruction is pain, and the passage and return of all things to their own nature is pleasure.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Let us accept that; for it seems to me to be true in its general lines.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then we may assume this as one kind of pain and pleasure arising severally under the conditions I have described?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Let that be assumed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now assume within the soul itself the anticipation of these conditions, the sweet and cheering hope of pleasant things to come, the fearful and woful expectation of painful things to come.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, indeed, this is another kind of pleasure and pain, which belongs to the soul itself, apart from the body, and arises through expectation.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You are right. I think that in these two kinds, both of which are, in my opinion, pure, and not formed by mixture of pain and pleasure, the truth about pleasure will be made manifest, whether the entire class is to be desired or such desirability is rather to be attributed to some other class among those we have mentioned, whereas pleasure and pain, like heat, cold, and other such things, are sometimes desirable and sometimes undesirable, because they are not good themselves, though some of them sometimes admit on occasion the nature of the good.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You are quite right in saying that we must track our quarry on this trail.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: First, then, let us agree on this point: If it is true, as we said, that destruction is pain and restoration is pleasure, let us consider the case of living beings in which neither destruction nor restoration is going on, and what their state is under such conditions. Fix your mind on my question: Must not every living being under those conditions necessarily be devoid of any feeling of pain or pleasure, great or small?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, necessarily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Have we, then, a third condition, besides those of feeling pleasure and pain?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, do your best to bear it in mind; for remembering or forgetting it will make a great difference in our judgement of pleasure. And I should like, if you do not object, to speak briefly about it.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Pray do so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You know that there is nothing to hinder a man from living the life of wisdom in this manner.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You mean without feeling pleasure or pain?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, for it was said, you know, in our comparison of the lives that he who chose the life of mind and wisdom was to have no feeling of pleasure, great or small.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, surely, that was said.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Such a man, then, would have such a life; and perhaps it is not unreasonable, if that is the most divine of lives.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly it is not likely that gods feel either joy or its opposite.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No, it is very unlikely; for either is unseemly for them. But let us reserve the discussion of that point for another time, if it is appropriate, and we will give mind credit for it in contending for the second place, if we cannot count it for the first.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now the other class of pleasure, which we said was an affair of the soul alone, originates entirely in memory.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We must, apparently, first take up memory, and perception even before memory, if these matters are to be made clear to us properly.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Assume that some of the affections of our body are extinguished in the body before they reach the soul, leaving the soul unaffected, and that other affections permeate both body and soul and cause a vibration in both conjointly and in each individually.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Let us assume that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we be right in saying that the soul forgets those which do not permeate both, and does not forget those which do?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do not in the least imagine that when I speak of forgetting I mean that forgetfulness arises in this case; for forgetfulness is the departure of memory, and in the case under consideration memory has not yet come into being; now it is absurd to speak of the loss of that which does not exist and has not yet come into being, is it not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then just change the terms.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Instead of saying that the soul forgets, when it is unaffected by the vibrations of the body, apply the term want of perception to that which you are now calling forgetfulness.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I understand.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the union of soul and body in one common affection and one common motion you may properly call perception.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then do we now understand what we mean by perception?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I think, then, that memory may rightly be defined as the preservation of perception.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite rightly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But do we not say that memory differs from recollection?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is this the difference?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: When the soul alone by itself, apart from the body, recalls completely any experience it has had in company with the body, we say that it recollects do we not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And again when the soul has lost the memory of a perception or of something it has learned and then alone by itself regains this, we call everything of that kind recollection.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now my reason for saying all this is—

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That henceforth we may comprehend as completely and clearly as possible the pleasure of the soul, and likewise its desire, apart from the body; for both of these appear to be made plain by what has been said about memory and recollection.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Let us, then, Socrates, discuss the next point.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We must, it seems, consider many things in relation to the origin and general aspect of pleasure; but now I think our first task is to take up the nature and origin of desire.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Then let us examine that; for we shall not lose anything.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Oh yes, Protarchus, we shall lose a great deal! When we find what we are seeking we shall lose our perplexity about these very questions.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is a fair counter; but let us try to take up the next point.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Did we not say just now that hunger, thirst, and the like were desires?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: They are, decidedly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What sort of identity have we in view when we call these, which are so different, by one name?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: By Zeus, Socrates, that question may not be easy to answer, yet it must be answered.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us, then, begin again at that point with the same examples.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: At what point?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We say of a thing on any particular occasion, “itÕs thirsty,” do we not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that means being empty?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is thirst, then, a desire?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, of drink.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Of drink, or of being filled with drink?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of being filled, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The man, then, who is empty desires, as it appears, the opposite of what he feels for, being empty, he longs to be filled.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is very plain.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, is there any source from which a man who is empty at first can gain a comprehension, whether by perception or by memory, of fulness, a thing which he does not feel at the time and has never felt before?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: It cannot be done.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And yet he who desires, desires something, we say.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And he does not desire that which he feels; for he is thirsty, and that is emptiness, but he desires fulness.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then somehow some part of him who is thirsty can apprehend fulness.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, obviously.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But it cannot be the body, for that is empty.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The only remaining possibility is that the soul apprehends it, which it must do by means of memory; for what other means could it employ?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No other, I should say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do we understand the consequences of this argument?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What are the consequences?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: This argument declares that we have no bodily desire.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because it shows that the endeavor of every living being is always towards the opposite of the actual conditions of the body.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the impulse which leads towards the opposite of those conditions shows that there is a memory of the opposite of the conditions.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the argument, by showing that memory is that which leads us towards the objects of desire, has proved that all the impulse, the desire, and the ruling principle in every living being are of the soul.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So the argument denies utterly that the body hungers or thirsts or has any such affection.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us consider a further point in connection with those very affections. For I think the purpose of the argument is to point out to us a state of life existing in them.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of what sort of life are you speaking, and in what affections does it exist?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In the affections of fulness and emptiness and all which pertain to the preservation and destruction of living beings, and I am thinking that if we fall into one of these we feel pain, which is followed by joy when we change to the other.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what if a man is between the two?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How between them?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because of his condition, he is suffering, but he remembers the pleasures the coming of which would bring him an end of his pain; as yet, however, he does not possess them. Well then, shall we say that he is between the affections, or not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Let us say so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we say that he is wholly pained or wholly pleased?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No, by Zeus, but he is afflicted with a twofold pain; he suffers in body from his sensation, and in soul from expectation and longing.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How could you, Protarchus, speak of twofold pain? Is not an empty man sometimes possessed of a sure hope of being filled, and sometimes, on the contrary, quite hopeless?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do you not think that when he has a hope of being filled he takes pleasure in his memory, and yet at the same time, since he is at the moment empty, suffers pain?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: It cannot be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: At such a time, then, a man, or any other animal, has both pain and pleasure at once.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, I suppose so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And when an empty man is without hope of being filled, what then? Is not that the time when the twofold feeling of pain would arise, which you just now observed and thought the pain simply was twofold?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very true, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us make use of our examination of those affections for a particular purpose.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: For what purpose?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we say that those pleasures and pains are true or false, or that some are true and others not so?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: But, Socrates, how can there be false pleasures or pains?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But, Protarchus, how can there be true and false fears, or true and false expectations, or true and false opinions?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Opinions I would grant you, but not the rest.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What? I am afraid we are starting a very considerable discussion.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And yet we must consider, thou son of that man,“Son of that man” may mean “son of Philebus,” in so far as Protarchus is a pupil of Philebus, or (so Bury) “son of Gorgias,” the orator and teacher (cf. Plat. Phaedo 58b), or the father of Protarchus may be referred to by the pronoun, possibly because Socrates does not at the moment recall his name or because he wishes to imply that he was a man of mark. whether the discussion is relevant to what has gone before.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We must dismiss everything else, tedious or otherwise, that is irrelevant.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now tell me; for I am always utterly amazed by the same questions we were just proposing.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are not some pleasures false and others true?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How could that be?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, as you maintain, nobody, either sleeping or waking or insane or deranged, ever thinks he feels pleasure when he does not feel it, and never, on the other hand, thinks he suffers pain when he does not suffer it?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: We have, Socrates, always believed that all this is as you suggest.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But is the belief correct? Shall we consider whether it is so or not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I should say we ought to consider that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then let us analyze still more clearly what we were just now saying about pleasure and opinion. There is a faculty of having an opinion, is there not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And of feeling pleasure?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And there is an object of opinion?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And something by which that which feels pleasure is pleased?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that which has opinion, whether right or wrong, never loses its function of really having opinion?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that which feels pleasure, whether rightly or wrongly, will clearly never lose its function of really feeling pleasure?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, that is true, too.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then we must consider how it is that opinion is both true and false and pleasure only true, though the holding of opinion and the feeling of pleasure are equally real.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, so we must.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You mean that we must consider this question because falsehood and truth are added as attributes to opinion, and thereby it becomes not merely opinion, but opinion of a certain quality in each instance?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And furthermore, we must reach an agreement on the question whether, even if some things have qualities, pleasure and pain are not merely what they are, without qualities or attributes.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Evidently we must.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But it is easy enough to see that they have qualities. For we said a long time ago that both pains and pleasures are great and small and intense.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if badness becomes an attribute of any of these, Protarchus, shall we say that the opinion or the pleasure thereby becomes bad?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Why certainly, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what if rightness or its opposite becomes an attribute of one of them? Shall we not say that the opinion is right, if it has rightness, and the pleasure likewise?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Obviously.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if that which is opined is mistaken, must we not agree that the opinion, since it is at the moment making a mistake, is not right or rightly opining?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what if we see a pain or a pleasure making a mistake in respect of that by which the pain or pleasure is caused? Shall we give it the attribute of right or good or any of the words which denote excellence?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is impossible if the pleasure is mistaken.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And certainly pleasure often seems to come to us in connection with false, not true, opinion.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course it does; and in such a case, Socrates, we call the opinion false; but nobody would ever call the actual pleasure false.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You are an eager advocate of the case of pleasure just now, Protarchus.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Oh no, I merely say what I hear.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is there no difference, my friend, between the pleasure which is connected with right opinion and knowledge and that which often comes to each of us with falsehood and ignorance?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: There is likely to be a great difference.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then let us proceed to the contemplation of the difference between them.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Lead on as you think best.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then this is the way I lead.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What way?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do we agree that there is such a thing as false opinion and also as true opinion?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: There is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And, as we were saying just now, pleasure and pain often follow them—I mean true and false opinion.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do not opinion and the power of forming an opinion always come to us from memory and perception?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do we, then, believe that our relation to these faculties is somewhat as follows?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Would you say that often when a man sees things at a distance and not very clearly, he wishes to distinguish between the things which he sees?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, I should say so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Next, then, would he not ask himself—

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: “What is that which is visible standing beside the rock under a tree?” Do you not think a man might ask himself such a question if he saw such objects presented to his view?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And after that our gazer might reply to himself correctly “It is a man”?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Or, again, perhaps he might be misled into the belief that it was a work of some shepherds, and then he would call the thing which he saw an image.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if some one is with him, he might repeat aloud to his companion what he had said to himself, and thus that which we called an opinion now becomes a statement?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if he is alone when he has this thought, he sometimes carries it about in his mind for a long time.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Undoubtedly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, is your view about what takes place in such cases the same as mine?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is yours?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I think the soul at such a time is like a book.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Memory unites with the senses, and they and the feelings which are connected with them seem to me almost to write words in our souls; and when the feeling in question writes the truth, true opinions and true statements are produced in us; but when the writer within us writes falsehoods, the resulting opinions and statements are the opposite of true.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is my view completely, and I accept it as stated.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then accept also the presence of another workman in our souls at such a time.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What workman?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: A painter, who paints in our souls pictures to illustrate the words which the writer has written.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: But how do we say he does this, and when?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: When a man receives from sight or some other sense the opinions and utterances of the moment and afterwards beholds in his own mind the images of those opinions and utterances. That happens to us often enough, does it not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: It certainly does.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the images of the true opinions are true, and those of the false are false?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Assuredly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if we are right about that, let us consider a further question.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Whether this is an inevitable experience in relation to the present and the past, but not in relation to the future.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: It is in the same relation to all kinds of time.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Was it not said a while ago that the pleasures and pains which belong to the soul alone might come before the pleasures and pains of the body, so that we have the pleasure and pain of anticipation, which relate to the future?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do the writings and pictures, then, which we imagined a little while ago to exist within us, relate to the past and present, but not to the future?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: To the future especially.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you say “to the future especially” because they are all hopes relating to the future and we are always filled with hopes all our lives?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Precisely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, here is a further question for you to answer.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
